Award.AwardTitle: BBSRC-NSF/BIO: IIBR Informatics: Collaborative Research: Inference of isoform-level regulatory infrastructures with studies in steroid-producing cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells are the fundamental units that provide functions needed to sustain life in living organisms. Cellular functions are carried out by proteins, products of genes, and the process of producing proteins from genes (i.e., gene expression) is mediated by complex regulation systems. Much remains unknown about the mechanisms of gene regulations. Given all genes in a cell, the regulatory relationships among genes can be represented by networks, called gene regulatory networks. It has been a long-standing challenge to reconstruct these networks experimentally and computationally. A gene can express multiple isoforms (mRNA molecules), and hence produces multiple different proteins, which makes the underlying gene regulatory networks more complicated. Recent advances in single cell RNA-Sequencing (scRNA-Seq) technology has brought new opportunities in resolving high-quality regulatory networks, but also posed new computational challenges. The project aims to computationally reconstruct accurate regulatory networks at the isoform-level from large-scale sequencing data. Educational and outreach activities, such as courses on topics in computational biology and inclusion of minority students, will be carried out.

The project will develop efficient approaches to identify expressed isoforms and to determine expression abundances, and then develop a network-reconstruction method which improves current state-of-art. The new computational methods will be validated and applied to the field of immunology--to study cellular mechanisms in steroid-producing cells. The project will make contribution in improvements over existing methods. First, the proposed methods for developing a scalable transcript assembler will enable accurate determination and quantification of the expressed isoforms, and make it possible to build regulatory networks at the level of isoforms to reflect the possible difference in regulatory mechanisms for different isoforms. Second, many recently developed methods for network inference require cells to be pre-ordered with trajectory inference or RNA-velocity to mimic time-series data. Errors in the cell ordering can mislead network inference and lead to false predictions. The project proposes to perform cell ordering and network inference simultaneously, which is expected to provide better results for both cell ordering and network inference. The project will reconstruct transcript-level regulatory networks for different types of steroid-producing cells from both published and newly generated single-cell data. POR.DRECONTENT:
Vision: Understanding how genes interact with each other, known as gene regulation, is a fundamental pursuit in biology. Recent advancements in single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) allow researchers to explore gene regulation at the individual cell level. This project aims to construct a gene regulation network at the isoform level and apply this framework to study the regulation of steroid-producing cells. Dr. Shao is leading Aim 1, which involves reconstructing full-length mRNA molecules in individual cells. These isoforms will serve as nodes in the gene regulation network, making this aim crucial to the overall project’s success.

 Intellectual Merits: We have developed novel algorithms to achieve highly accurate assembly at single-cell resolution. Specifically:

1. We proposed to develop scalable data structures and algorithms to represent and combine scRNA-Seq data. This was accomplished by creating a "combined graph," which organizes all splicing information from individual cells. The construction of this combined graph is a foundational part of our meta-assembler, Aletsch.

2. We proposed to design more scalable algorithms to decompose combined splice graphs with phasing paths. This was achieved through a novel algorithm that decomposes a graph in multiple rounds, applying different vertex selection strategies in each round. A consensus approach then selects paths and isoforms present in multiple decompositions. This algorithm is now integrated into the multi-sample assembler, Scallop2.

3. We proposed to develop robust and accurate algorithms to jointly quantify and assemble scRNA-Seq data. We developed robust algorithms using a machine learning model, specifically a random forest, trained to accurately score assembled isoforms. This approach is implemented within our meta-assembler Aletsch.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research is integrated with education and outreach, broadening its impact. Specifically:

1. Advancing biological discovery: The assembly methods (Scallop2 and Aletsch) enable accurate isoform-resolution gene regulation network construction. These tools are being applied to study the immune cell-mediated steroidogenesis pathway in cancer, potentially leading to therapeutic discoveries.

2. Developing course materials: Dr. Shao regularly teaches the "Algorithms for Transcript Assembly" module for the course Genomics (MCIBS/BMMB 551) at Penn State. The research and outcomes, including Scallop2 and Aletsch, are incorporated into this teaching.

3. Disseminating and supporting open-source software: All methods are available as open-source software at https://github.com/Shao-Group. Both Scallop2 and Aletsch are distributed via conda, making installation easy on multiple platforms.

4. Promoting diversity: Dr. Shao used this grant to support two female PhD students.

Summary of Research Outcomes: This grant has yielded 11 peer-reviewed publications. Scallop2 and Aletsch stand out as the most significant outcomes, substantially improving the accuracy of reconstructing full-length isoforms from single-cell RNA-seq data. These tools are vital not only to this project’s success but are also widely used in gene expression analysis.
